I strongly believe that gay marriage should be legalized. Frankly, there's no compelling argument against it. Many people claim that homosexual couples jeopardize the traditional family, but this overlooks the myriad complexities involved. It's like comparing two sides of the same coin; they're fundamentally the same, just differently oriented. The civil rights at stake here—property taxes, health care, and hospital visitation—are too significant to ignore. If you're in a committed relationship, shouldn't your partner have the same rights as any other spouse? Scientific studies show that gay couples experience similar relationship satisfaction rates to heterosexual couples, so why not grant them the same legal recognition? People often get hung up on the religious aspect, but in a civil context, shouldn't the government provide the same legal documents to all couples, regardless of their religious beliefs? It's like legal segregation—separate but unequal. The issue of adoption and community influence is also overblown. Children of gay parents are no different from others; their upbringing and societal acceptance depend more on the quality of their parents' relationships and community support. The federal government should step in and legalize gay marriage across all states. While President Bush's religious views may influence his stance, it's hypocritical for the government to enforce religious standards while ignoring the cultural and moral diversity in America. Many people oppose gay marriage due to misconceptions about psychological damage, but the American Psychological Association has debunked these claims. We should rely on research and evidence, not popular or religious opinions, to guide our policies.

Man, I was alright with the whole Iraq situation at first, but we were all still reeling from 9/11. The Bush administration used the Iraq war as a smokescreen. They pinned it on Bin Laden and Saddam Hussein's WMDs, which we now know was all just hot air. It's like they lied to our faces, and I mean, even Powell's now admitting he wasn't convinced back then. That's like an impeachable offense right there!

I mean, they've been trying to marginalize the Constitution since 9/11. It's like they came into office ready to go to war, and it's not just about oil, though that's a big factor too. I think they've had it out for Saddam Hussein since Dad's days, and I'm not sure if this coalition idea is going to work either. I mean, Syria and Saudi Arabia? Really? And the interim government? It's a mess. The Parliament's a joke, and even our old enemy, al-Sadr, has a seat now. It's like we're just throwing money into a black hole. I don't know, maybe I'm just ranting, but it's been a long time and it's not getting any better.

You know, I struggle with this topic. The War in Iraq, it's a mess. I mean, it's not even a declared war, right? It feels like we just wanted to get back at them for 9/11. Who knows who really did it, but we bombed them anyway. I'm not really into the details, but I know we're there now to build democracy, and oil, and it's just not worth the upset we've caused. It's going to take forever to create a democracy, and if we leave, they'll start over from scratch. It's a big old mess. And the more we stay, the worse it gets. We're wasting resources, and it's making Bush look like a terrible president. Vietnam was undeclared, and it's labeled a meaningless war now. If we continue, he'll be remembered the same way. It's like, how long can this go on? Families are affected, and it's hard to want it to end. But if we stay, we're trying to mold them into us, and that's just going to make things worse. It's a complex situation.

Let me be clear, I'm not convinced that it's right to legalize or for a state to declare it as legal. I believe it's primarily the church's responsibility, as the constitution acknowledges the separation of church and state. It's not just a clear statement, it's a fundamental principle. Attempting to impose rules or power over it would be a defiance of what's already been established in the constitution. It's the government deciding what's allowed for one church over another, especially since most Catholics and Christians, except for those in Boston and similar areas, are against it. The separation of church and state is a cornerstone of our constitution, a key aspect of religious tolerance in the US. Even planning an amendment on this would contradict what's already written and could be one of the few amendments used to restrict people rather than the government. I don't think the federal government or any government should be involved. The push for this amendment seems to be more about one religion's beliefs than anything else. I think it's up to the churches to decide, not the president or any government officials. There's no real reason behind the push for an amendment except personal beliefs. It might even boost the economy and society, but I'm not sure how. I've said all I want to.

I feel like the war has dragged on much longer than it should have. Initially, the purpose seemed noble - to restore democracy in a country without a fair political system. However, I believe we have since lost sight of that goal. The war has become a means to an end, perhaps to prove our superpower status. The original motivation may have been questionable, influenced by George Bush's father's past disputes with Saddam Hussein. If the initial goal was to establish democracy, I could understand that; however, I have my doubts about the personal matters involved. I think we clearly made our statement in the first few months of the war; at this point, it has become far too prolonged. If our purpose was to free a country oppressed by a tyrant, that could be justified. But I believe our reasons have become muddled and misguided. It seems we're still at war to prove a point, seeking a decisive victory. I think it's time to bring this to an end. There comes a point when a country must stand on its own, and our economy is suffering from the cost. We should be spending these billions on our own issues, like poverty and public education, rather than on a war that has lost its cause. We're draining our economy for a purpose that has become obsolete.

Can I pose a query to clarify something?

You know, the privacy issue I'm wrestling with is... somebody found something online and used it to prevent a potential catastrophe, but am I wrong in thinking that this step crossed some privacy lines?

Honestly, I don't think so. On platforms like Myspace, if you post your life online, it's pretty much for everyone to see. You have to agree to become someone’s “friend” to view their profile, right? That’s giving them permission to snoop. The moment you put anything on the internet, you're inviting a lot of people to peek.

But here’s the tricky part: who’s watching? Can you imagine a whole team of people monitoring every student’s profile to prevent some misdeed? That sounds like discrimination, right? I’m not sure how that's fair. But if someone randomly stumbles upon something suspicious or is actually investigating for evidence, maybe it’s okay.

I don’t have a Myspace, but I’m on Facebook. It’s bothering me that there are creepy individuals out there who can see bits about me. I’ve seen scenarios where people gain access to others' profiles fast. It's scary how easy it is, and it hits close to home when you see someone you don’t recognize messaging you, knowing your schedule, your friends, and all.

I don't want to totally restrict my profile, as one of the reasons I'm on it is to stay connected with friends. But I have to be careful, as you never know who’s looking.

My roommate mentioned that in high school, there was an uproar when the school banned students from having Myspace. That seemed a bit too much, didn’t it? I mean, how can school officials dictate such personal choices? I'm not sure it’s a clear-cut privacy issue, but it felt like an overreach of authority to me.

That’s about all I can think of for now.

Well, let me clarify that they didn't exactly legalize it; they decriminalized it. That means instead of being a criminal offense, it's more like a traffic ticket. You know, something you get cited for rather than being arrested and booked. And sure, getting caught and cited can have impacts, like a drug charge, but it's less severe than it used to be.

The main concern is the future ramifications. Even when it's decriminalized, it's still a worry for job interviews and such. But there's also an economic argument. Arresting, booking, and housing people costs a lot. And when you add up the court appearances and the legal fees, it's a significant expense. So, some financially struggling communities aren't willing to make that kind of change, even if it would free up money for other things.

But in more open-minded places, like Denver, I think it's fine. They must have more money now, which they can put towards public education, social programs for the elderly, and food for the homeless. It's about finding a balance. Marijuana shouldn't be everywhere, but there are financial benefits to consider.

I'm not sure how I feel about it being sold openly like cigarettes. That could lead to smoking and driving, and it's still taboo in many places. But if it's made legal, we need to figure out how to handle it responsibly.

Some people know how to handle substances, while others don't. It's really hard to generalize about the impact of substances. But I think they both have their drawbacks.

So, if the states can come to some kind of agreement, then they should strive to make it a federal law, but amending the constitution just for this? That's stretching it. Growing up in a Christian household, homosexuality was always a murky issue for me. I've got plenty of LGBTQ+ friends, and while I don't necessarily agree with their lifestyle, I believe it should be legalized. It's not something that should be a national debate, every state should decide for itself. Democratic states will naturally lean towards legalizing gay marriage, and I wouldn't argue with their decision because they're the ones electing to live there. I don't think the president should decide for the entire country, especially if he's not from that state. That's not how the states' rights work. Bush can't decide how every state should run, and he'll be out of office soon enough. If a Democratic president lifts the ban on gay marriage, it'll just flip-flop back and forth. It's best to leave it to the individual states to decide, after all, they're the ones who'll have to live with the consequences.

Oh, no, I don't think so. Let's consider this. Myspace is a public platform, and that's essentially what it was designed for—to put messages out there for everyone to see. The same goes for posting on the internet. If you put something out there, you know it's going to be seen by others, potentially even school officials. So, in my view, school officials have every right to access that information, even if it's not posted under the school's name. Now, if they're doing it to prevent a school shooting, well, that's a whole different ballgame. They have a responsibility to keep students safe, and if that involves monitoring online activity, then I think that's perfectly fine. But if they're just snooping around to catch students in trouble, that's an invasion of privacy. So, it's a delicate balance. I don't believe they should be constantly trolling the internet, but if they come across something that might put the school or students at risk, then it's their duty to act. I mean, parents drop their kids off at school expecting a safe environment, right? So, it's understandable that the school would want to ensure that. But they should have clear guidelines and manage it responsibly.

I strongly believe that gay marriage should be legalized. Frankly, there's no compelling argument against it. Many people claim that homosexual couples jeopardize the traditional family, but this overlooks the myriad complexities involved. It's like comparing two sides of the same coin; they're fundamentally the same, just differently oriented. The civil rights at stake here—property taxes, health care, and hospital visitation—are too significant to ignore. If you're in a committed relationship, shouldn't your partner have the same rights as any other spouse? Scientific studies show that gay couples experience similar relationship satisfaction rates to heterosexual couples, so why not grant them the same legal recognition? People often get hung up on the religious aspect, but in a civil context, shouldn't the government provide the same legal documents to all couples, regardless of their religious beliefs? It's like legal segregation—separate but unequal. The issue of adoption and community influence is also overblown. Children of gay parents are no different from others; their upbringing and societal acceptance depend more on the quality of their parents' relationships and community support. The federal government should step in and legalize gay marriage across all states. While President Bush's religious views may influence his stance, it's hypocritical for the government to enforce religious standards while ignoring the cultural and moral diversity in America. Many people oppose gay marriage due to misconceptions about psychological damage, but the American Psychological Association has debunked these claims. We should rely on research and evidence, not popular or religious opinions, to guide our policies.

Man, I was alright with the whole Iraq situation at first, but we were all still reeling from 9/11. The Bush administration used the Iraq war as a smokescreen. They pinned it on Bin Laden and Saddam Hussein's WMDs, which we now know was all just hot air. It's like they lied to our faces, and I mean, even Powell's now admitting he wasn't convinced back then. That's like an impeachable offense right there!

I mean, they've been trying to marginalize the Constitution since 9/11. It's like they came into office ready to go to war, and it's not just about oil, though that's a big factor too. I think they've had it out for Saddam Hussein since Dad's days, and I'm not sure if this coalition idea is going to work either. I mean, Syria and Saudi Arabia? Really? And the interim government? It's a mess. The Parliament's a joke, and even our old enemy, al-Sadr, has a seat now. It's like we're just throwing money into a black hole. I don't know, maybe I'm just ranting, but it's been a long time and it's not getting any better.

You know, I struggle with this topic. The War in Iraq, it's a mess. I mean, it's not even a declared war, right? It feels like we just wanted to get back at them for 9/11. Who knows who really did it, but we bombed them anyway. I'm not really into the details, but I know we're there now to build democracy, and oil, and it's just not worth the upset we've caused. It's going to take forever to create a democracy, and if we leave, they'll start over from scratch. It's a big old mess. And the more we stay, the worse it gets. We're wasting resources, and it's making Bush look like a terrible president. Vietnam was undeclared, and it's labeled a meaningless war now. If we continue, he'll be remembered the same way. It's like, how long can this go on? Families are affected, and it's hard to want it to end. But if we stay, we're trying to mold them into us, and that's just going to make things worse. It's a complex situation.

Let me be clear, I'm not convinced that it's right to legalize or for a state to declare it as legal. I believe it's primarily the church's responsibility, as the constitution acknowledges the separation of church and state. It's not just a clear statement, it's a fundamental principle. Attempting to impose rules or power over it would be a defiance of what's already been established in the constitution. It's the government deciding what's allowed for one church over another, especially since most Catholics and Christians, except for those in Boston and similar areas, are against it. The separation of church and state is a cornerstone of our constitution, a key aspect of religious tolerance in the US. Even planning an amendment on this would contradict what's already written and could be one of the few amendments used to restrict people rather than the government. I don't think the federal government or any government should be involved. The push for this amendment seems to be more about one religion's beliefs than anything else. I think it's up to the churches to decide, not the president or any government officials. There's no real reason behind the push for an amendment except personal beliefs. It might even boost the economy and society, but I'm not sure how. I've said all I want to.

I feel like the war has dragged on much longer than it should have. Initially, the purpose seemed noble - to restore democracy in a country without a fair political system. However, I believe we have since lost sight of that goal. The war has become a means to an end, perhaps to prove our superpower status. The original motivation may have been questionable, influenced by George Bush's father's past disputes with Saddam Hussein. If the initial goal was to establish democracy, I could understand that; however, I have my doubts about the personal matters involved. I think we clearly made our statement in the first few months of the war; at this point, it has become far too prolonged. If our purpose was to free a country oppressed by a tyrant, that could be justified. But I believe our reasons have become muddled and misguided. It seems we're still at war to prove a point, seeking a decisive victory. I think it's time to bring this to an end. There comes a point when a country must stand on its own, and our economy is suffering from the cost. We should be spending these billions on our own issues, like poverty and public education, rather than on a war that has lost its cause. We're draining our economy for a purpose that has become obsolete.

Can I pose a query to clarify something?

You know, the privacy issue I'm wrestling with is... somebody found something online and used it to prevent a potential catastrophe, but am I wrong in thinking that this step crossed some privacy lines?

Honestly, I don't think so. On platforms like Myspace, if you post your life online, it's pretty much for everyone to see. You have to agree to become someone’s “friend” to view their profile, right? That’s giving them permission to snoop. The moment you put anything on the internet, you're inviting a lot of people to peek.

But here’s the tricky part: who’s watching? Can you imagine a whole team of people monitoring every student’s profile to prevent some misdeed? That sounds like discrimination, right? I’m not sure how that's fair. But if someone randomly stumbles upon something suspicious or is actually investigating for evidence, maybe it’s okay.

I don’t have a Myspace, but I’m on Facebook. It’s bothering me that there are creepy individuals out there who can see bits about me. I’ve seen scenarios where people gain access to others' profiles fast. It's scary how easy it is, and it hits close to home when you see someone you don’t recognize messaging you, knowing your schedule, your friends, and all.

I don't want to totally restrict my profile, as one of the reasons I'm on it is to stay connected with friends. But I have to be careful, as you never know who’s looking.

My roommate mentioned that in high school, there was an uproar when the school banned students from having Myspace. That seemed a bit too much, didn’t it? I mean, how can school officials dictate such personal choices? I'm not sure it’s a clear-cut privacy issue, but it felt like an overreach of authority to me.

That’s about all I can think of for now.

Well, let me clarify that they didn't exactly legalize it; they decriminalized it. That means instead of being a criminal offense, it's more like a traffic ticket. You know, something you get cited for rather than being arrested and booked. And sure, getting caught and cited can have impacts, like a drug charge, but it's less severe than it used to be.

The main concern is the future ramifications. Even when it's decriminalized, it's still a worry for job interviews and such. But there's also an economic argument. Arresting, booking, and housing people costs a lot. And when you add up the court appearances and the legal fees, it's a significant expense. So, some financially struggling communities aren't willing to make that kind of change, even if it would free up money for other things.

But in more open-minded places, like Denver, I think it's fine. They must have more money now, which they can put towards public education, social programs for the elderly, and food for the homeless. It's about finding a balance. Marijuana shouldn't be everywhere, but there are financial benefits to consider.

I'm not sure how I feel about it being sold openly like cigarettes. That could lead to smoking and driving, and it's still taboo in many places. But if it's made legal, we need to figure out how to handle it responsibly.

Alcohol can definitely affect your driving, but marijuana often has a more disruptive effect on lifestyle. Both have adverse effects, and no two people react the same way. Some people know how to handle substances, while others don't. It's really hard to generalize about the impact of substances. But I think they both have their drawbacks.

Man, I haven't quite figured out where I stand on this issue yet. I mean, it's such a fine line to tread between the separation of church and state, and determining what marriage really is. It's tricky, you know? You see, if we start looking at marriage through the lens of the government, it's like questioning someone's faith. Civil unions don't get tax breaks, so why should they be treated differently? I guess if we're talking plainly, it's just two people joining together. That's what it's all about. So, if the states can come to some kind of agreement, then they should strive to make it a federal law, but amending the constitution just for this? That's stretching it. It's too much for something that's not huge enough to warrant such a change. It's just not important enough to alter the constitution to define or ban gay marriage. That's all.

Growing up in a Christian household, homosexuality was always a murky issue for me. I've got plenty of LGBTQ+ friends, and while I don't necessarily agree with their lifestyle, I believe it should be legalized. It's not something that should be a national debate, every state should decide for itself. Democratic states will naturally lean towards legalizing gay marriage, and I wouldn't argue with their decision because they're the ones electing to live there. I don't think the president should decide for the entire country, especially if he's not from that state. That's not how the states' rights work. Bush can't decide how every state should run, and he'll be out of office soon enough. If a Democratic president lifts the ban on gay marriage, it'll just flip-flop back and forth. It's best to leave it to the individual states to decide, after all, they're the ones who'll have to live with the consequences.

Oh, no, I don't think so. Let's consider this. Myspace is a public platform, and that's essentially what it was designed for—to put messages out there for everyone to see. The same goes for posting on the internet. If you put something out there, you know it's going to be seen by others, potentially even school officials. So, in my view, school officials have every right to access that information, even if it's not posted under the school's name. Now, if they're doing it to prevent a school shooting, well, that's a whole different ballgame. They have a responsibility to keep students safe, and if that involves monitoring online activity, then I think that's perfectly fine. But if they're just snooping around to catch students in trouble, that's an invasion of privacy. So, it's a delicate balance. I don't believe they should be constantly trolling the internet, but if they come across something that might put the school or students at risk, then it's their duty to act. I mean, parents drop their kids off at school expecting a safe environment, right? So, it's understandable that the school would want to ensure that. But they should have clear guidelines and manage it responsibly.

I strongly believe that gay marriage should be legalized. Frankly, there's no compelling argument against it. Many people claim that homosexual couples jeopardize the traditional family, but this overlooks the myriad complexities involved. It's like comparing two sides of the same coin; they're fundamentally the same, just differently oriented. The civil rights at stake here—property taxes, health care, and hospital visitation—are too significant to ignore. If you're in a committed relationship, shouldn't your partner have the same rights as any other spouse? Scientific studies show that gay couples experience similar relationship satisfaction rates to heterosexual couples, so why not grant them the same legal recognition? People often get hung up on the religious aspect, but in a civil context, shouldn't the government provide the same legal documents to all couples, regardless of their religious beliefs? It's like legal segregation—separate but unequal. The issue of adoption and community influence is also overblown. Children of gay parents are no different from others; their upbringing and societal acceptance depend more on the quality of their parents' relationships and community support. The federal government should step in and legalize gay marriage across all states. While President Bush's religious views may influence his stance, it's hypocritical for the government to enforce religious standards while ignoring the cultural and moral diversity in America. Many people oppose gay marriage due to misconceptions about psychological damage, but the American Psychological Association has debunked these claims. We should rely on research and evidence, not popular or religious opinions, to guide our policies.

That's like an impeachable offense right there!

I mean, they've been trying to marginalize the Constitution since 9/11. It's like they came into office ready to go to war, and it's not just about oil, though that's a big factor too. It's a complex situation.

Let me be clear, I'm not convinced that it's right to legalize or for a state to declare it as legal. I believe it's primarily the church's responsibility, as the constitution acknowledges the separation of church and state. It's not just a clear statement, it's a fundamental principle. Attempting to impose rules or power over it would be a defiance of what's already been established in the constitution. It's the government deciding what's allowed for one church over another, especially since most Catholics and Christians, except for those in Boston and similar areas, are against it. The separation of church and state is a cornerstone of our constitution, a key aspect of religious tolerance in the US. Even planning an amendment on this would contradict what's already written and could be one of the few amendments used to restrict people rather than the government. I feel like the war has dragged on much longer than it should have. Initially, the purpose seemed noble - to restore democracy in a country without a fair political system. However, I believe we have since lost sight of that goal. The war has become a means to an end, perhaps to prove our superpower status. The original motivation may have been questionable, influenced by George Bush's father's past disputes with Saddam Hussein. If the initial goal was to establish democracy, I could understand that; however, I have my doubts about the personal matters involved. I think we clearly made our statement in the first few months of the war; at this point, it has become far too prolonged. If our purpose was to free a country oppressed by a tyrant, that could be justified. But I believe our reasons have become muddled and misguided. It seems we're still at war to prove a point, seeking a decisive victory. I think it's time to bring this to an end. There comes a point when a country must stand on its own, and our economy is suffering from the cost. We should be spending these billions on our own issues, like poverty and public education, rather than on a war that has lost its cause. We're draining our economy for a purpose that has become obsolete.

Can I pose a query to clarify something?

You know, the privacy issue I'm wrestling with is... somebody found something online and used it to prevent a potential catastrophe, but am I wrong in thinking that this step crossed some privacy lines?

Honestly, I don't think so. On platforms like Myspace, if you post your life online, it's pretty much for everyone to see. You have to agree to become someone’s “friend” to view their profile, right? That’s giving them permission to snoop. The moment you put anything on the internet, you're inviting a lot of people to peek.

But here’s the tricky part: who’s watching? Can you imagine a whole team of people monitoring every student’s profile to prevent some misdeed? That sounds like discrimination, right? I’m not sure how that's fair. But if someone randomly stumbles upon something suspicious or is actually investigating for evidence, maybe it’s okay.

I don’t have a Myspace, but I’m on Facebook. It’s bothering me that there are creepy individuals out there who can see bits about me. I’ve seen scenarios where people gain access to others' profiles fast. It's scary how easy it is, and it hits close to home when you see someone you don’t recognize messaging you, knowing your schedule, your friends, and all.

I don't want to totally restrict my profile, as one of the reasons I'm on it is to stay connected with friends. But I have to be careful, as you never know who’s looking.

My roommate mentioned that in high school, there was an uproar when the school banned students from having Myspace. That seemed a bit too much, didn’t it? I mean, how can school officials dictate such personal choices? I'm not sure it’s a clear-cut privacy issue, but it felt like an overreach of authority to me.

That’s about all I can think of for now.

Well, let me clarify that they didn't exactly legalize it; they decriminalized it. That means instead of being a criminal offense, it's more like a traffic ticket. You know, something you get cited for rather than being arrested and booked. And sure, getting caught and cited can have impacts, like a drug charge, but it's less severe than it used to be.

The main concern is the future ramifications. Even when it's decriminalized, it's still a worry for job interviews and such. But there's also an economic argument. Arresting, booking, and housing people costs a lot. And when you add up the court appearances and the legal fees, it's a significant expense. So, some financially struggling communities aren't willing to make that kind of change, even if it would free up money for other things.

But in more open-minded places, like Denver, I think it's fine. They must have more money now, which they can put towards public education, social programs for the elderly, and food for the homeless. It's about finding a balance. Marijuana shouldn't be everywhere, but there are financial benefits to consider.

I'm not sure how I feel about it being sold openly like cigarettes. That could lead to smoking and driving, and it's still taboo in many places. But if it's made legal, we need to figure out how to handle it responsibly.

Alcohol can definitely affect your driving, but marijuana often has a more disruptive effect on lifestyle. Both have adverse effects, and no two people react the same way. Some people know how to handle substances, while others don't. It's really hard to generalize about the impact of substances. But I think they both have their drawbacks.

Growing up in a Christian household, homosexuality was always a murky issue for me. I've got plenty of LGBTQ+ friends, and while I don't necessarily agree with their lifestyle, I believe it should be legalized. It's not something that should be a national debate, every state should decide for itself. Democratic states will naturally lean towards legalizing gay marriage, and I wouldn't argue with their decision because they're the ones electing to live there. I don't think the president should decide for the entire country, especially if he's not from that state. That's not how the states' rights work. Bush can't decide how every state should run, and he'll be out of office soon enough. If a Democratic president lifts the ban on gay marriage, it'll just flip-flop back and forth. It's best to leave it to the individual states to decide, after all, they're the ones who'll have to live with the consequences.

Oh, no, I don't think so. Let's consider this. Myspace is a public platform, and that's essentially what it was designed for—to put messages out there for everyone to see. The same goes for posting on the internet. If you put something out there, you know it's going to be seen by others, potentially even school officials. So, in my view, school officials have every right to access that information, even if it's not posted under the school's name. Now, if they're doing it to prevent a school shooting, well, that's a whole different ballgame. They have a responsibility to keep students safe, and if that involves monitoring online activity, then I think that's perfectly fine. But if they're just snooping around to catch students in trouble, that's an invasion of privacy. So, it's a delicate balance. I don't believe they should be constantly trolling the internet, but if they come across something that might put the school or students at risk, then it's their duty to act. I mean, parents drop their kids off at school expecting a safe environment, right? So, it's understandable that the school would want to ensure that. But they should have clear guidelines and manage it responsibly.
